That assurance comes on the back of a long history of our being told one thing by the BBC and ITV, but seeing another. That was particularly the case with ITV when it was Granada. At the time of licence renewal, when there was talk of how the obligations under the licence would be met in terms of comprehensive coverage of a region. The promised coverage simply does not materialise. Unless there is enforcement by the regulator, I have little faith that the undertakings entered into will be met. Ofcom tells me that it is determined to ensure that enforcement takes place and that it will monitor things closely, although I have to confess that I do not know what measures can be taken if people are once again in breach. The history in our region is one of increasing withdrawal from the commitments to the intra-regional coverage that we have been led to expect.

When we met Ofcom, I was particularly taken with one idea—that of the public service publisher. I have had the opportunity to speak to others and to read a little about that and it seems to be an extremely welcome idea. I understand that the public service publisher would be based in one of the regions away from the normal centres of media activity. No one will disagree with that. The idea has great potential to allow many things to happen at even sub-regional or local community level. A friend of mine, Mike Short, who used to be a producer for "World in Action", has involved himself in a co-operative exercise called Toxteth Television in the south end of Liverpool, and he is looking at a venture in my constituency in the north end of Liverpool. The idea is to enable communities to have access to the airwaves in a way that is meaningful to them and results in broadcasting that reflects their interests, instead of some of the tripe that is recycled by terrestrial and other broadcasters and force-fed to the nation. Perhaps such ventures will begin to release some of the great television potential that has hitherto gone unrealised.

We have great hopes for that idea in terms of its being located in the north-west and fitting in with the north-west digital platform. The north-west digital platform is not an easy concept for people such as me, who are na-ve about broadcasting technology, to take in, but my understanding is that it will act as a gateway for the multitude of potential channels that will be open from 2008, with the onset of digitalisation. The question is how that can best be used to the advantage of all—producers and consumers—and to enhance the quality of broadcasting in every sense. It has been developed through Mersey Television and is supported by other organisations in the north-west and by people such as John Roberts of United Utilities, who is a prominent supporter of it, and John Bills of Trinity Mirror group newspapers. Those substantial individuals can see the merits of the north-west digital platform, how it can fit neatly with the public service publisher, and how it will, in turn, affect small community groups. I quoted Toxteth Television—a local group in my city—but with the new technologies would be equally appropriate to Tower Hamlets television.

Referring to my earlier comments about the huge reservoir of talent that we have on Merseyside, the new technology means that we can use that talent, not only for the benefit of our local community, but for the benefit of communities and producers throughout the United Kingdom. Merseyside already has some advantages—as well as talent, I believe that we are the most wired-up city, literally and metaphorically, in the United Kingdom. We have the technology in place with which to do some marvellous things.
I bear in mind Ofcom's own definition of the public service publisher and what it is intended to do. It is to be
"charged with developing services and content that take full advantage of new distribution technologies . . . a free-to-view premier content service and community services."

I hope that the Minister will respond with some encouraging words about the public service publisher, and where he thinks that that idea will end up. Although I understand that he cannot make a pledge on behalf of Merseyside any more than he can make a pledge on behalf of Sheffield, he will understand the arguments that are being made: that we do not want a London-centric broadcasting industry to be replaced by a London-and-Manchester-centric broadcasting industry. The new technologies allow us to be far more diverse than has hitherto been possible. We are entering an era in which we will have the choice instantaneously between watching a biopic of Mother Teresa or looking at the Chubby Chasers website, whatever our predilection might be. That is the kind of opportunity that the technology allows. It gives freedom of choice for the individual to access all the many sources of broadcasting.
I have a particular concern about some of the weaknesses in current legislation—

That is one of those fables that are best left to gather dust. It originates with my hon. Friend the Member for Ealing, North (Mr. Pound), who is fond of fabricating exotic tales about people's status on even more exotic websites.

I return to the subject of the north-west digital platform. In 1989 Granada was challenged for the ITV franchise by North West Television, which offered to put the north-west into television service. Hon. Members will remember well the bold and imaginative plan to turn the focus away from being part of what was then regarded widely as a national cartel, and is now a national plc, to becoming a stand-alone, regionally focused broadcaster that made programmes for the north-west. There was nothing too dramatic in that, but it was a little too radical for its time. Sixteen years have passed, technology has moved on and the consolidation foreseen by North West Television has now begun. The people who identified with the region in the Bernstein era have all gone. It is fair to say that that arm of television has just become another business. It has lost the distinctiveness that Granada used to have.

We need a clear and simple mechanism of communication, knowledge transfer and information exchange and exhibition, as well as some celebratory space for people in the north-west in what will become a crowded and cluttered digital landscape. We do not know exactly where we shall go, but we are worried that, unless we are careful, we will be inundated not only with choice, but with mediocrity so lacking in clear identity that it would be a disservice not to flag up such matters now.

ITV is in retreat from regional programmes. Channel 4 and Five are national by definition. Both the public service publisher to which I alluded and the north-west digital platform are exciting and valid, but unproven concepts. We must look for a wee bit of certainty. In today's statement, the Secretary of State said that she had left an opening so that that the funding regime might change at some point in the future, but I thought that that was an vague comment. I certainly hope that the Government are not considering doing it in the short term. Will my right hon. Friend the Minister clarify the position?

At present, only one public service broadcaster—the BBC—by its remit and by funding, reaches from national to regional to truly local services through, for example, its strong local radio services in my home town. The BBC wants to play to that strength and has announced plans to base a series of local digital television services on its existing local radio network, but there are difficulties with that and such proposals need to be thought through. The whole point about the technology is that developments are ongoing and not yet complete, and we do not know what the outcomes will be. We must be prepared to make the best and most varied possible use of those developments.

I wish to refer briefly to the move to Manchester by the BBC, which gave rise to the debate. The BBC is to move between 1,700 and 1,800 people to Manchester by 2010, but my research with the Manchester Evening News shows that, with independents moving there, too, the number of people moving might be between 2,500 and 3,000, which is a sizeable number. It is not for me to say to the BBC which of its departments it moves to Manchester, but it strikes me that BBC Online could well be based in Merseyside and enhance its service rather than have it diminished by the move. We have to be careful with new technology because of the provisos that I gave about it still being developed, but we have to recognise that location is not the determinant of where a service is best provided. Look at Manchester, where—once again—we will end up with empire building. The old Manchester building houses 700 or 800 people now, but a new centre is to be built and new hard infrastructure provided. Is that needed in Manchester?

I do not want to sound as though I am carping and whinging about Manchester and its success. I wish Manchester all the very best. It has done some good things, not least in television. In the old days, it provided not only the light entertainment typified by Granada's "Coronation Street", but some very good investigative programmes, such as "World in Action". I would not detract from Manchester's history or its capacity and ability to promote itself and do well, but I honestly believe that when we look at the totality of the north-west—a heavily populated, relatively compact but region—I question whether the concentration of facilities and investment in Manchester is something for the north-west as a whole to be pleased about.

I should point out our history. At one time, television facilities were promised—indeed, they were provided at one stage—by ITV, or Grenada as it then was, in Lancaster, Preston, Liverpool and Chester. However, the ITV company clawed back from that provision, starting with the "This Morning" show with Richard and Judy, which was produced in Merseyside but was pulled out and taken to London. ITV has a mere token presence in Liverpool now. Not long ago, I asked it about the building in Liverpool in which it is housed, and I was told that it would be the base from which it would cover Liverpool's year of being the European capital of culture in 2008. However, I read the following week in the local newspaper that it was selling the building to national museums and galleries on Merseyside.

We have a history of not getting a fair share of the pie, and I do not believe that we are getting a fair share now. The truth of the matter is that the technology allows businesses—whether the BBC or ITV—to locate in a whole variety places. ITV is now being consolidated into one company, but despite its best wishes and the 50 per cent. of regionally produced programmes, I believe that ITV will become more London-centric. All Manchester is doing is following what happened for a while in the 70s. We are consolidating the BBC on two sites instead of one. I do not think that it is meeting the regional requirement in terms of jobs or best value. It is not reflecting, in any shape or form, what I understand still to be a prime requirement on both independent television and the BBC: ensuring that there is regional content that really reflects regional needs and diversity.

I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Kilfoyle) on securing this important debate. I am a big supporter of BBC North West and ITV, but I believe that both organisations as they stand now are failing the north-west public. Regional programmes and news have declined in recent years, and the quality and content of the programmes is on a downward spiral. If both ITV and the BBC are to justify their charter and licence obligations, we should be able to expect high standards from both organisations. As far as I can see there is reduced coverage of local and national political issues. There is a lot less coverage of Westminster and party conferences. I was amazed to discover that ITV no longer had a desk at party conferences. ITV journalists wandered around without a base. It was difficult for politicians who wanted to talk to them about some of the issues that were being addressed at the conference to get in touch with them. It is certainly a step backwards, in my view.

The current affairs programmes that we see on both BBC and ITV in the north-west are of a lower quality and the coverage is not what it used to be. Most of the current programmes are of the "Kilroy" variety. They take complex issues and turn them into soundbites. They prefer to provoke political punch-ups than to get to the bottom of a complex issue or to inform the general public. They are more of an entertainment. They deal with trivia, gossip and scandal. A typical example would be the recent programme in which a prospective parliamentary candidate was selected. I do not know whether any other Members watched that, but I watched with horror as a racist was eventually chosen as the most suitable candidate to stand in the forthcoming general election. That is unacceptable television. It drags standards down even lower.

Given that Jim Hancock's contribution is like a pearl cast before swine compared with so much of the rest, who does my hon. Friend think is responsible for allowing the programme makers or the commissioning editors to steadily degrade the quality of the shows on offer on television?

The responsibility lies with the management of those organisations. The north-west group of MPs will be inviting the head of the regional programme news to a meeting to discuss some of the issues that we are raising here today. Generally most of us are dissatisfied with the management of both those organisations as regards regional programming. It will be difficult to change both organisations. When I speak to representatives of the BBC and ITV, they seem to think that politicians should support them because they are there. They say, "Well, we are Granada and we have existed for many years, so just support us." The only justification for granting a charter, and for allowing people to be charged a licence fee, is that the broadcasters provide good-quality programmes and deal with regional issues. If they fail to do that, we will have to look at other forms of media, and my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton has suggested ways to do that.

There must be a complete review of both those organisations. The regulator needs to look far more closely at the content of their programmes. He also needs to hold them to the agreements they made when the charters were first signed, because I do not believe that they are maintaining the conditions of their charter. They should be challenged on a regular basis if that can be proved, and I think evidence could be provided to demonstrate that.

I think so. I hope that the decentralisation of BBC services will be a continual programme, and that over the coming years more and more of those functions will be put out to the regions. I certainly think they should be spread around regions; I do not see why Manchester or Liverpool, or any one centre, should get the whole of the operation.

Frankly, I think that the BBC is very bad at managing its resources. People quite rightly criticise the size of the licence fee and the amount of money that the general public have to pay for the BBC. The least it can do is ensure that it is as cost-efficient as it can be. It cannot be cost-efficient while the majority of the programmes and the majority of the organisation are based in London. That runs counter to any logical argument. The second thing that people can expect from the BBC is higher quality. It should set the targets for other media and broadcasters to follow. It is running scared of satellite services. It is dumbing down programmes and running after the same sort of audience. In doing so, it is doing a disservice to itself and to the general public.

Our democratic system relies on the information flow to the general public. If we are not going to use the television systems—the BBCs and the ITVs—to get over the complex issues and to start to debate them, and to explain what we are doing in places such as this one about addressing those serious issues, how will we have a thriving democracy?

It is about time that the Government took a tough line with these people and set out clear, precise, rational ideas about what they want from the BBC and from the independent ITV services. The regulator should take a much tougher line if they fail to meet standards. We want to see them not just once every five years or whenever the charter is renewed. We should have a regular review to ensure that they are delivering what they promised. In terms of both the BBC and ITV services, failures are taking place.

I hope that this debate will start one within the BBC and ITV and I hope that they will start to realise that they cannot take the support that I think they enjoy from most people in this Room unless they deliver the product that we expect them to. It is a sad day when MPs have to stand up and say that.

I am not having a go at individuals in the BBC or ITV. I like most of the people who work in both those services. Many of the creative people and the people in front of the camera understand what we are saying. If they were not employed by those organisations, they would be making the same points as myself and my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton have made today. I hope that the management will start to examine the issue. We need to hand some things back.

My hon. Friend is far more knowledgeable about these things than I, but I take the point that he made. We do not just want the existing services decentralised to our region. We want our region to be able to develop its own programmes and to focus on local issues in current affairs, general programmes and news. We want a north-west based service that deals with north-west issues.

It is ironic that when I meet people in the media round here they often come from the north-west. My hon. Friend just mentioned one such person. It is amazing. One falls over such people down here. All those people have to travel down to London to make a career in television and it is a disgrace. As I said, it makes no economic or cultural sense. The sooner we get back to a system where the BBC represents us all and not just a small elite in London, the better.
I, too, congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Kilfoyle) on his good fortune in securing this debate and on the comprehensive way in which he introduced the subject.

We are all anxious to emphasise that this is not another scouser whinge. We are not complaining that Manchester is getting a bigger share of the cake or voicing sub-regional enmity towards Manchester based on football rivalry or some esoteric event in the past. We are certainly not going to bring the hon. Member for Henley (Mr. Johnson) into the debate; enough has been said on that subject. What my hon. Friend has described is a systemic failure. Large corporations do not know how to provide services that are essentially regional in character—that is the truth of the matter. The business logic of their position is always to go back to what they know best and centralise everything, usually in London. My hon. Friend, other people and I have tried to address these problems over the years, and he rehearsed the arguments more fully than I need to. Repeatedly, we have been given assurances about services that would be located on Merseyside and for a short while they have been, but as soon as it has become inconvenient to maintain them, away they go. Until the next time there is some negotiation about charters or licence fees, the issue is completely forgotten about. That is how large corporate bodies operate.

I listened to the statement made by the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, my right hon. Friend the Member for Dulwich and West Norwood (Tessa Jowell) in the Chamber this afternoon. I was particularly encouraged by what she said about regional broadcasting—that "To reflect the whole of the United Kingdom and its different and diverse communities, the BBC also needs to make sure that a significant slice of production takes place outside London. It needs to provide a specific range of services for the UK's nations and regions. People should see the full diversity of the UK and their local communities reflected in mainstream as well as regional programming." That is what is to happen in the BBC, and is precisely the direction in which my hon. Friends the Members for Liverpool, Walton and for St. Helens, North (Mr. Watts) and I are trying to steer provision.
Generally, I agree; I simply did not want to get involved in a debate about proportions, although I intend to cover how such matters should be guaranteed in future. My hon. Friends make a good point.

My first point is similar to one made by my hon. Friend the Member for St. Helens, North about what gets covered by whom and where. The current preoccupation in news and current affairs is with headline issues. If there is a big issue in Liverpool and stations have someone available, they might send a film crew out to cover it, but there are all sorts of things going on below the radar that nobody covers.

I have a specific example. On Monday morning my hon. Friend and I attended an event in his constituency organised by the Young Women's Christian Association. It involved a group of—from what I could gather—teenage and single mothers talking about the difficulties that they experienced. Their agenda was for better buggy access to public transport and more breastfeeding facilities in all sorts of places. What took place was a fascinating discussion about how they got to where they were, the problems that they face and what they think that schools should have done. I will not bore the Chamber with what they think about men in general, but it is not very flattering. That would have made fascinating television, but who turned up? The St. Helens Star, Radio Merseyside and a couple of other print journalists attended, but nobody from the television companies did so, even though it would have been a fascinating film. Such activity is replicated all over Merseyside, and probably all over the north-west, and nobody expresses the slightest interest in it.

My second point, to which my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton also referred, is that there is an enormous amount of talent. Liverpool John Moores university, with which I have an association as an alumnus and as the father of another graduate—my oldest son—has an excellent facility for training film and television programme makers. In fact, it covers the whole gamut of media studies—a branch of learning that takes a knocking in some quarters but covers a growing market with a growing number of jobs. There are talented people on Merseyside but, as my hon. Friend the Member for St. Helens, North said, they mostly end up having to go somewhere else. How do young potential programme and film makers get into the corporations that have the power to commission programmes? I do not know how, but there are some things that can be done to encourage them.

The same is true of young musicians. My hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton is involved in the Mersey music industry and was instrumental in the organisation of a very good concert in support of UNICEF. There are a lot of young musicians about, but how do they ever get showcased? Who takes any interest in them? If there were another Beatles out there, would anybody actually spot them? I do not know that anybody is producing the music programmes that provide local or regional opportunities.
As ever, my hon. Friend adds great weight to my argument. A serious amount of young talent is simply not being tapped, but what can be done about it?

My hon. Friend mentioned the potential of a north-west digital platform. Like my right hon. Friend the Minister, when I was young I trained in engineering, but as my family will confirm, I am so technophobic now that my sister-in-law managed to receive 14 texts from my new mobile phone that I never sent. I am hopelessly incompetent with technology, and if I were to show the next part of my speech to my family they would laugh loudly.

The north-west digital platform is made up of three constituent parts: first, a digital television channel; secondly, a digital content hub and, thirdly, a broadband internet site—that is how my hon. Friend managed to link it into his Chubby Chasers website, about which he earlier refused to reveal more. That is the basic proposal from Phil Redmond of Mersey Television, who says:

"The platform will initially occupy a dedicated television channel available on digital satellite (BSkyB), digital terrestrial (Freeview) and digital cable (Telewest e.g.). This channel will become the region's digital shop-window promoting and showcasing regionally produced content, products and services on a free-to-air basis."
That is where we want to go. That is how all that young talent will be identified and developed.

At this stage, it is only a proposal on the Secretary of State's desk, but Ofcom is proposing a public service publishing fund of £300 million. A public service publisher means something slightly different from the traditional publisher. There will be an access fund—a way of commissioning that is outside the stultifying central way of doing things at present. I support Ofcom's proposal, which provides a means by which the deficiencies that we have described can be put right. It is important not only to get the money in place but to ensure that the fund is properly administered in a way that meets the regional objectives and that it can be accessed by independent people outside ITV, Five, Channel 4 and the BBC. The only way we will expand regional input and output is by encouraging more independent people to be involved and giving them the means to do it.

To return to the point made by my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton in an intervention, my right hon. Friend the Minister should ensure that such matters are nailed down in legislation where that is appropriate, or, if it is not appropriate, in proper regulations. Too many promises have been made that were never delivered because there was no statutory basis on which they were given. If Ofcom says that something will be done, it should be codified and monitored to ensure that it actually does what it says it will do.

The BBC have an obligation to consider the potential on Merseyside—my hon. Friends and I include St. Helens, Knowsley and Sefton as well as Liverpool in that area, and my hon. Friend the Member for Wirral, South (Mr. Chapman) would add Wirral, too. The potential is there and if BBC Online can be relocated, I hope that my hon. Friend and his ministerial colleagues will point the BBC in the direction of Merseyside because we have a great deal to offer.

There are many things that can be done and there is a great deal of potential out there. I hope that the Government, whom I support in almost everything, will act as the catalyst to ensure that the potential is used to make programmes and films, that performing is encouraged and that they ensure that the fascinating things that are going on below the radar are broadcast so people can see what is going on at community level.

When I entered the room, I was genuinely horrified to hear the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Kilfoyle) speaking. I know that that is a common reaction, but in my case it was because I had mistimed the sitting. My hon. Friend the Member for Bath (Mr. Foster) asked me to speak on his behalf in this debate and, despite my grovelling apologies for being late, that decision will have a beneficial outcome, because I can guarantee that I will be even more supportive of the general thrust of the hon. Gentleman's argument—possibly even more so than my hon. Friend.

I was sorry to miss the first part of the hon. Gentleman's contribution. He has bravely broken the golden rule of the politician, which is not to annoy the media—a rule to which I subscribe in most circumstances. Very few people break that rule. The Mayor of London is an exception and the hon. Member for St. Helens, North (Mr. Watts) has done it to some extent on this occasion, but politicians normally do not do it. People might have expected the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton to defer to that rule and not put his city before transient popularity, but he seems to have done precisely the reverse.

There is a false choice on offer, because the BBC can genuinely be persuaded that it is in its interest to look harder at Liverpool. That is not an anti-Manchester point, but a recognition of the position that I hope the BBC will bear in mind. The BBC needs to take into account important sub-regional interests and genuine sub-regional differences, which should be reflected in regional broadcasting. I welcome the move of the BBC and its executive to the north. In turn, the BBC should welcome the wealth and diversity of talent that it will find there and recognise that, whatever it thinks, the north-west is not homogenous and that centralisation exclusively in Manchester might be a mistake.

We are all aware, as are broadcasters in Merseyside, how poor the BBC facilities are. I understand that there is only one small studio in Paradise street that contains little modern, up-to-date equipment and requires considerable technical assistance from the Manchester end. That is not desirable in Liverpool, a capital of culture and one of Britain's major cities. I concur with the sentiments of the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton and I support their general thrust.

Public service broadcasting in general was mentioned by the hon. Member for St. Helens, North, who has observed, as do we all, what I call the tabloidisation of the BBC and its tendency to reduce serious issues to simple conflicts of opinion. One can understand to some extent the BBC's point of view—it feels obliged to demonstrate that it can get the ratings to justify the money that it charges the public, so it has two competing objectives: first, to get the ratings, and secondly, to be a responsible public service broadcaster. The result is a muddle, because those are two different things: one deals with what is attractive to the public and the other deals with what is important to the public, and the two things do not necessarily coincide. There is a resolution to that difficulty for the BBC, which is to make the genuinely important things attractive. That is not impossible; it can and should be done.

I concur with the sentiments expressed by other hon. Members. Regional journalism, whether in the broadcast media or the press, and even local journalism in our own areas, is in many ways individualistic, sharp-edged. It has a great deal to contribute. Since coming to Westminster, I have been amazed by the somewhat herd-like tendencies of the parliamentary lobby and the national media. Perhaps I may give a recent, slightly controversial example. If I were to tell my local press that I was to make an announcement about something on Monday, they would say, "Well, we'll wait until Monday. You go ahead and do it and we will report you then." However, I note that in their pre-election run-up the Conservatives tell us each Sunday what they will announce on Monday and receive massive coverage throughout the BBC. That strikes me as a bizarre journalistic response, but that is by the bye.

I congratulate the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Kilfoyle) on obtaining the debate on a day when broadcasting is particularly topical and when most of us are focusing on the BBC. I hope that that will mean that his remarks receive even greater attention than they would otherwise.

As a Member of Parliament who represents a constituency in Essex, which is some way removed from north-west England, I take a relatively neutral position in the debate between Manchester and Liverpool. The hon. Gentleman is correct to say that, when I read the subject of his debate on the Order Paper, I was not entirely clear what he wished to pursue. He informed me helpfully of that before the debate, so I shall be brief.

When I spoke to the hon. Gentleman, I was not entirely clear myself about the subject matter of the debate. He should not be put off by the fact that he represents an Essex constituency. After all, the hon. Member for Henley (Mr. Johnson) received copious coverage in the north-west not so long ago.
It is my hon. Friend's experience that causes me to be even more cautious and perhaps more brief than I would usually be.

The hon. Gentleman said that ITV had apparently shown little interest in his debate, but I want to say a few words in defence of ITV. It sent me a brief on its activities in the north-west for use in the debate, which I shall be happy to share with him after our discussions if he has not seen it. ITV has been a regionally structured entity. We have recently seen the coming together of the regional companies to form ITV plc, which is probably in the interests of ITV in the new, much more competitive broadcasting environment. We have also received assurances, which I hope will be kept to, that ITV will remain very much regionally focused. Granada, its regional company in the north-west, is perhaps one of the best-known companies—if not the best known—in the group. ITV has made clear to me that it employs 1,000 core staff in the region and that it contributes £150 million to the creative economy in the north-west, which I understand is now the heart of ITV's children's programming.

The hon. Member for St. Helens, North (Mr. Watts) referred to the controversial production, "Vote for Me", which I, too, watched with some horror. Having seen the effect on the music industry of "Pop Idol", I was concerned that "Vote for Me" might have a similar effect on the House of Commons. The fact that almost no one watched it is therefore of some comfort to me. I do not think that we can expect Mr. Hilton-Potts to arrive here after the general election.

The hon. Gentleman is right to distinguish between regional production and regional programming; they are totally different, and the quota I mentioned is for regional production. However, I also want to talk about regional programming, because that is important in terms of reflecting the way of life in the north-west. It is an expensive activity for ITV to undertake—indeed, in some cases, the regional production quotas may increase costs. Ofcom rightly identifies a problem in that ITV is having to compete against broadcasters that are not subject to public service obligations, and the value that ITV currently enjoys from having access to the analogue spectrum is diminishing as a result of the steady growth of digital penetration. Ofcom rightly flagged up the problems ITV will face, which led it to recommend that the obligation for non-news and current affairs regional programming should be reduced.

Two hon. Members referred to the Ofcom proposal for a public service publisher. I do not find that option attractive: I am not drawn to the idea of creating another nationalised broadcaster at a time when there is a proliferation of channels. However, I regret the Secretary of State's apparent dismissal of the recommendation of Lord Burns to allow commercial broadcasters to have access to licence fee money. We understand that that was supported by Lord Birt in No. 10 Downing street, but it did not find favour in the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. I regret that, because that recommendation provides a potential solution to the problem that ITV will face in maintaining public service broadcasting. If people believe that it is important that commercial television companies continue to offer regional programming, whether from the north-west or elsewhere, supporting them to do so seems an appropriate use of public money . That could have been achieved under that recommendation in the Burns report.

ITV is a commercial company. It must compete and survive in the marketplace, unlike the BBC. The BBC receives £2.8 billion of public money and is rightly subject to strong public service obligations. It has something like 27,000 employees, and I entirely share the feelings expressed by the hon. Member for St. Helens, North about visiting television centre and seeing miles and miles of corridors. There is no question that it is expensive to produce programmes in London and the south-east, and the BBC has a duty to be present across the whole of the United Kingdom. For that reason, I support, so far as it goes, the transfer of programme making away from London to Manchester. I understand the feeling of the Merseyside Members here today that Manchester may not seem a huge improvement on London. The BBC, on the other hand, says that the move will help to create a hub of media excellence, which is what it is trying to do in Manchester.

Where I feel the BBC could do more, and from which Merseyside could benefit—as would every area of the United Kingdom—would be to increase by a significant amount the proportion of its programmes made by independent production companies. The Government imposed on the BBC a requirement to meet a 25 per cent. quota of independent production. It is a disgrace that, for a number of years in succession, the BBC has failed to meet that quota. It has now said that it will view it as an absolute minimum and has talked about creating a window of opportunity for the next 25 per cent. I was interested in the Secretary of State's remark a couple of hours ago that she feels that that may not go far enough. I certainly do not feel that it goes far enough. The BBC has enormous power to encourage the creative economy in Merseyside and throughout the United Kingdom by investing more in independent production. I urge the Secretary of State to do more than just consider that.

The other area that I should like to touch on is radio. When discussing broadcasting, it is very easy to concentrate on television and forget about radio. Radio is very locally based and some of the most successful radio stations are plugged into the centre of their communities. I also welcome, therefore, the opportunities that the Communications Act 2003 will provide for even more localised radio stations, such as community radio.

I end by agreeing strongly with the hon. Member for Liverpool, Walton about the potential for alternative forms of broadcasting, particularly the internet and through the growth of new technology. There is no doubt that the world is changing very rapidly indeed. In some ways, the idea of the BBC or ITV dominating the broadcasting sector will not survive for much longer. As we move into an age of multimedia convergence, the opportunities for extremely localised broadcasting—Toxteth Television or the Chubby Chasers website, which I am clearly going to have rush from the Chamber to access—represent a potentially very important new sector in the media. I congratulate the hon. Gentleman on obtaining this debate and wish him well in his efforts to attract even more of the creative economy into his city.

speech.speakeroffice: The Minister for Sport and Tourism
speech.p: I shall try to remain within the confines of the title of the debate—broadcasting in the north-west of England—and not stray too far from that. I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Walton (Mr. Kilfoyle) on securing the debate. He knows as well as other hon. Members who have participated that it has been the subject of a number of Adjournment debates in the House. There is tremendous interest in regional television, particularly in an age when broadcasting is increasingly a global business. I am particularly reassured to see some much affection for programmes that reflect the identities of different groups and regions around the country. I suppose, to use the jargon, that it is a case of "think globally, act locally".

I should like to take this opportunity to emphasise the Government's real commitment to the regional dimension of public service broadcasting. That has been reflected this afternoon in the statement on the broadcasting Green Paper made by my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State. We also built it into the Communications Act 2003, ensuring that broadcasters continue to invest time and money in producing high quality programmes for the regions.

A key challenge that now faces the regulator—Ofcom—is how public service obligations, such as programming for the nations and the regions, can best be maintained in a period of rapidly increasing competition and the huge impact of digital take-up. That is where Ofcom's review of public service television broadcasting and the future extent of regional broadcasting on commercial channels become important. The third and final phase of Ofcom's review was published a few weeks ago and has been fed into the charter review process. The charter review Green Paper has been published today.

An important part of Ofcom's review is the examination of ITV's public service obligations and the requirements placed on it to produce a certain amount of regional programming. Those obligations are set out in the 2003 Act, and Ofcom has the responsibility of implementing them. Notably, it has to define what constitutes, in the words of section 287 of the Act, a "sufficient amount" of regional programming in the context of ITV's overall public service obligations. As has already been indicated, ITV has already pledged £50 million to ensure continued investment in its regional network production.

As the hon. Member for Maldon and East Chelmsford (Mr. Whittingdale) said, that was the subject of debate during the passage of the Communications Act. It is Ofcom's responsibility under section 287 of the 2003 Act to determine what is a "sufficient amount" of regional programming.

As I said, ITV has already pledged £50 million to ensure continued investment in its regional network production. That will secure a move to more out-of-London production. ITV has shown further commitment to regional news by beginning a £40 million investment programme in its digital news centres across the UK.

Ofcom is therefore faced with some hard choices. Those who disagree with its conclusions that the current regional broadcasting quotas are unsustainable need to be able to demonstrate either that ITV can sustain all its public service broadcasting obligations regardless of the impact of increased competition, or that some other element of its obligations should be removed.

I am glad to see that the Under-Secretary of State for Health, my hon. Friend the Member for South Thanet (Dr. Ladyman)—the Minister for Thanet—is here. We shall be able to resume our discussions—and possibly our duels—on this matter.

I want to focus on acute services in my constituency. However, it is worth saying at the outset that there has recently been steady progress on many fronts on health in my constituency. For instance, in the past those who had had strokes were often left with very little support or assistance. However, recently a new stroke unit at Hemel Hempstead hospital has been offering a much-extended and appropriate service. I should like to place on the record my thanks to the many voluntary bodies that campaigned so hard for that, including Dacorum hospital action group, and to the Government for having the courage to increase national insurance by 1p to raise the funds to improve our health services.

Although similar developments for some other serious conditions are at an earlier stage in terms of effective provision, I am encouraged by the Minister's recent reply to me about the provision of nursing specialists for conditions such as Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis. In general, there has been a very welcome focus on the plight of those with chronic long-term conditions. For that group to be helped, health services need to be willing to have a close liaison with social services. Hertfordshire has been a leading authority in making progress in that area, with explicit Government support. A good Government produce real benefits, particularly for those groups of people who have reached a time of life or who are in such a condition that they need the help of others. In that regard, the Government are a good Government carrying out their mandate. However, it is inevitable that in an Adjournment debate I should focus on those areas in which the train looks a bit as if it is coming off the rails. That is my intention in this debate.

As far as the community that I represent is concerned, the body that occasions so much grief is called the Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire strategic health authority. I want to make it clear that I realise that health provision needs to be planned outside the scope of a single constituency—or possibly that of a single county, although that would be more difficult. However, a lot of the complaints that I wish to make relate very much to the people who have been given that job and how they have chosen to do it.

It was pretty unusual that a newspaper advert by the Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire health authority—"Healthcare fit for Herts"—was taken to the Advertising Standards Authority, which found that the advertisement was deceptive. That is an astonishing thing to happen to a public body, and there ought to be much more public accountability when that kind of thing happens. Recently, that health authority had another shot: "Better care for sick children", it said. In that advertisement it talked about there being a bigger, purpose-built ward, although we know that beds for children in the area are going to be reduced from 35 to 26. That advertisement too will doubtless end up at the Advertising Standards Authority, but this time we would welcome the Minister's interest in the fact that a public body has used public money to give a demonstrably false impression to the public.

It has not simply been that. An edition of the Health Service Journal recently had a brief headline; the letter F was followed by three stars, which were followed by the word "off". One does not need to be a genius to work out what the stars stood for. That expression was used repeatedly by the chief executive of the strategic health authority and was directed at the chief executive of the West Hertfordshire Hospitals trust at a Christmas dinner.

The result of that exchange was that it made the headlines of the Health Service Journal, as it should, as an example of the sort of behaviour that should not be tolerated in public servants. It also occasioned the resignation of the chief executive of that trust, someone who had the trust of the community that I represent. The person who preceded the current occupant of the chief executive's chair of the strategic health authority, John de Braux, also had that trust.

The previous incumbent was Jane Herbert. She made every effort to understand the Hertfordshire health economy and the role that Hemel Hempstead hospital in particular, and the large undeveloped site next to it, could play in trying to secure improved health provision for the people of my constituency and those around it.

I put it to the Minister that not simply is such behaviour, on the face of it, at least problematic, but it is extremely strange that there seems to be no way in which that behaviour can be called into question, as it should be.

The advertisement that I mentioned gave what I can only call a pernicious interpretation of a health strategy that people have been using. The pernicious interpretation involves projecting forward to 2012, when, we are told, there will be marvellous new facilities at Hatfield and Watford. I have in front of me an artist's impression of a field, which is yet to be designated, and a wonderful new hospital at Hatfield. So far, so good. I hope that the people of Hatfield enjoy their new facility. That is not the issue. The issue is whether, as part of that strategy, we should be planning for a reduction of level of service in certain areas of the county.

On Monday, I went to a meeting to discuss the reconfiguration of children's services in my area; it was not a reconfiguration, but a contraction—from a significant number of beds to rather less. The pernicious interpretation of the strategy involves the idea of creating a hospital at Watford one day, costing, let us say, £330 million. It will be accessible by some kind of monorail from Hemel Hempstead, which will get people there in, let us say, 10 minutes. I suspect that if that were the case, there might not be too much worry in my constituency about the health facilities that people need being quite far away. As it stands, they could be enormously far away.

That does not apply only to health. In 1993, my local further education college was combined with a college in Watford. Then, all the services at Hemel Hempstead began to be contracted. As a result, there is little FE provision for my constituents, because Watford is too far away. Kids stay on at school doing unsuitable subjects, because the alternatives are non-existent.

The Government say that they want national health service customers to have choice. My constituents want the choice of being treated in their local hospital, not only because it is convenient and gives them a good service, but because as things stand Watford is a hospital in the process of demolition. To move a service from a perfectly functioning hospital with a large number of new facilities to a hospital that is in the process of being demolished is entirely perverse.

If that is the strategy, one should at the very least make the best possible use of the excellent hospital at one's disposal, while perhaps reconfiguring services or doing demolition jobs at the target hospital. Indeed, that is exactly what has happened elsewhere in Hertfordshire in the relationship between Stevenage hospital and hospitals in the Welwyn Hatfield area. Services have been established at Stevenage to try to ensure that at least Stevenage plays an appropriate role in the transition process, which is anything but finalised and has yet to get even an outline business case.

Why is not Hemel Hempstead playing such a role? The answer is, because we are severely disaffected with the strategic health authority. It wants to ensure that we are brought into line by effectively taking every decision as quickly as it can in what I can only describe as a malevolent way. There is no rational argument here. The language that is used and the advertisements that we are forced to plough through, all have the effect of marginalising the process of rationality.

One of the issues that we have tried to get across repeatedly—utterly unsuccessfully so far, but with the Minister's help perhaps that can change—is the fact that efforts are being made to get a regeneration programme going in Hertfordshire. I have taken a particular interest in that regeneration programme because there is land in my constituency that is in public ownership and not in the green belt. Without any infraction on amenity space it could provide a site for a significant programme of affordable housing for our youngsters and for the next generation.

That land is potentially available and yet whenever we mention that Hemel Hempstead might take some of the regeneration that Hertfordshire is expected to achieve, there has never been any suggestion of trying to improve the health infrastructure to service that enlarged community. That is not because it is not a reasonable thing to request, but because we have a health authority that is entirely unreasonable and deaf to rational argument. When I put those arguments to the strategic health authority board there was a stony silence. When the board asked whether there were any questions, the answer was "No." There were no questions, no interest and no engagement. The response was simply, "Mr. McWalter, you are from Hemel Hempstead. You are out of the loop and the quicker you get out of the room, the better." Well, we are not going away.

There is a desperate democratic deficit in all this. I sat in a room on Monday and people on a top table had the power of decision in these matters. Where was their democratic mandate? I represent a parliamentary constituency. I ought to have a say. But the people who were taking the decision included the chair of the local primary care trust. She voted in favour of these proposals. I think she was leant on somewhat, but I cannot believe that more than 1 per cent. of my constituents would vote in favour of these plans. The main political parties at the next election will all be opposed to them. If somebody stood at the next election on a pro-strategic health authority ticket—a "Consolidate Children's Services at Watford" party—I wonder exactly how many votes they would get. The only votes would be from people who accidentally put their cross in the wrong box. Yet the chair of the primary care trust voted for them and not for the huge majority of people in my area. That is a democratic deficit.

We are also told that the Government will not carry out any major reconfiguring of services. That is bad news for the strategic health authority because it really does not like Dacorum primary care trust. It is the oddball—the one that the authority could not bribe its way to get. I use that term not in the sense of personal benefits but in the sense that when Watford looked as though it would oppose the plans, along came a £330 million development to stuff its mouth with gold and ensure that it came into line. My constituency was never offered that. The reality now is that the strategic health authority has decided that our primary care trust does not need its own chief executive, so it will give us a joint one. Who with? Watford. Where is she based? Watford. There is a de facto joining together of primary care trusts to quieten further the voice of my constituents on these important matters.

Many people in the country are seeing the benefits of having a Government who have had a passion for health and a commitment to improvement, to making an investment in our health services and to changing tack from the story of asset stripping and provision reduction that characterised health in the 1980s and 1990s. That resulted in proposals that all Hertfordshire hospitals should close, that there should be only one and that the system should be much smaller to be economical. We fought off the report proposing that, called "The Right Approach", and we fought off a number of other threats.

This debate is not about the closure of Hemel Hempstead hospital but about service displacement, irrationality, profligacy and an authority that should be much more democratically accountable than it is now. I ask the Minister to review the events that I have described with a view, as I have asked before, to suspending those who treat people in such a way, to inquiring into the falsehoods perpetrated in advertisements and, eventually, to giving us some people whom we can trust to listen to our arguments.

speech.speakeroffice: The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Health
speech.p: I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Hemel Hempstead (Mr. McWalter) on yet again securing a debate on this matter. I know that it is of great concern to him and his constituents. I responded to the debate that he secured in December 2003, I have had meetings with him, and my officials and I have studied the reports that he has written in recent months. He has for many years been a fervent supporter of his local hospital and the services that it provides. Whatever else his constituents may have concerns about, they can be sure that they have a Member of Parliament who is tireless in campaigning on their behalf.

Like the people of Hemel Hempstead, my hon. Friend is eager to secure the high-quality health services that any community should expect. That vision is shared by the Department of Health and the local national health service in Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire. I am sorry that he feels that advertisements placed by the strategic health authority have been unfair or misleading. Misleading adverts should not be placed, and I shall be interested to hear the views of the Advertising Standards Authority.

It is a fact that we need to change if we are to improve. Our health care system is under pressure. Patients are still waiting too long for their operations, and many hospitals are in a poor state and need updating. My hon. Friend is absolutely right. The huge amount of money that the Government are putting into health care is driving improvements nationally, including in his constituency, but we still have a lot to do, and those pressures need to be addressed. That has been the case for many years, but we realise that we in Whitehall cannot make decisions about local matters, because we do not know areas as well as local people do. That is why, under our "Shifting the Balance of Power" policy, we pushed decision making down to local areas.

Frankly, across Beds and Herts some health services, particularly the major hospitals, are unlikely to be able to deliver the quality of, and continuous improvement in, care that we expect in England in the 21st century. In West Herts the situation is particularly acute, with the local trust zero star rated. The NHS cannot accept that, and the local NHS is right to demand that it be addressed. That is why there was an initial process to consider changes in health care in the area. That was followed by a formal public consultation known as "Investing in Your Health", which ran from March to December 2003.

Due process was followed in that matter. When local NHS organisations have under consideration a proposal for service change they must comply with the consultation requirements of sections 7 and 11 of the Health and Social Care Act 2001. Section 7 requires the NHS to consult relevant overview and scrutiny committees on service changes that are of a substantial nature. Nobody disputes that the changes described by my hon. Friend are of a substantial nature. Section 11 requires NHS organisations to consult and involve patients, the public and their representatives in the planning and development of services, and in decisions affecting the operation of services.

Following the consultation process, the scrutiny committees had the opportunity to refer the issue to my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State for Health for intervention. They did not do so. As a result—I know that this will and does upset my hon. Friend—even if he were able to convince me of his case, I have no basis for intervention in this matter. It was a matter for local determination, and decisions must now remain with the local NHS.

During the consultation period, two options for the future reconfiguration of hospital services were proposed. Both entailed retaining six major hospitals in Beds and Herts, including Hemel Hempstead and Watford general hospitals. As my hon. Friend is aware, option 2 was preferred, which would mean a new hospital at Hatfield with a cancer centre, and development of Watford hospital as a major acute hospital and Hemel as a major non-acute hospital.

I appreciate that that is not the option preferred by my hon. Friend, but this is not about winners and losers; it is about benefits for users of health services across the two counties, and that was the major driver for change. Following on from the consultation process, last April and again in June Department of Health officials reviewed the deliverability of the proposals decided upon by the local NHS, and they were satisfied that they were deliverable. In particular, they were satisfied that the two proposed major acute developments could fit on their proposed sites and meet the highest NHS design and space standards; that the proposals were properly costed and likely to be affordable within a reasonable projection of the health community's resources; that the authority had already completed a significant public consultation, in which the proposals were supported by the vast majority of stakeholders—I accept that that does not include my hon. Friend and his constituents—and that the trusts and the strategic health authority understood the challenge of delivering the scheme, and were committed to making the necessary project management resources available.

An earlier peer review by the capital investment unit for the London strategic investment unit formed similar conclusions. As a result, the scheme was approved by Ministers and announced last July. The scheme is now finalising its procurement strategy and recruiting to its project team so that it can develop its outline business case with a view to procurement commencing in 2006 or early 2007, and construction potentially starting in 2009. I want to assure my hon. Friend that under option 2, Hemel Hempstead hospital has a future and will receive investment of around £25 million to develop it into a modern, high-quality major hospital specialising in planned surgery.

I also understand that Dacorum primary care trust is developing plans for the site, including an intermediate care facility and possibly a general practitioner surgery and mental health in-patient facilities. I am assured that Hemel hospital will have more patient contacts than Watford and will continue to play a vital role in health service provision for the people of Hertfordshire.

My hon Friend has raised concerns today about the children's consultation process. May I state clearly that no decision has been made? I understand that Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire strategic health authority has honoured the commitment given during the "Investing in Your Health" consultation process to talk with local people about how it achieves the services laid out in option 2. I am pleased to note that over the past few months the health authority has been listening to the views of local people on the proposals and important issues, such as the opening times for the Hemel children's accident and emergency unit and the design of the new units.

At a meeting held on Monday, which was open to the public, the proposals on the children's review were unanimously agreed. My hon. Friend might have views as to whether the chairman of the local PCT should have agreed them, but the fact was that they were unanimously agreed. Some of these proposals include a children's rapid assessment unit at Hemel hospital open 12 hours a day, every day, alongside the main accident and emergency department; a rapid referral clinic run alongside the children's out-patient departments at Hemel Hempstead and Watford, offering an alternative to treatment in accident and emergency; a new, specially designed children's day unit at Hemel Hempstead hospital, staffed by specialist children's doctors and nurses and providing planned treatment and surgery; an enhanced community nursing team to ensure that more children could be cared for at home; and a children's in-patient ward at Watford hospital.

I would advise my hon. Friend to get access to the national service framework for children, which we have recently published, and compare the proposals with the best practice that is set out in the national service framework. If he does not believe that the proposals match that best practice guidance, that would provide him with valuable ammunition with which to challenge the proposals.

I also appreciate my hon. Friend's concerns regarding the single chief executive for the two local primary care trusts, but may I remind him once again that that is a local decision for the local PCT trust board? I understand that both PCTs are happy with the current arrangements.

My hon. Friend also raised concerns about transport around Watford hospital. I am aware that a transport and access group, drawn from a range of bodies, is studying how public transport can be improved.

In the final minute available to me, I shall deal with the points made by my hon. Friend in respect of the national position and put them in context. The latest round of revenue allocations to PCTs, covering the period 2006–07 and 2007–08, were announced on 9 February 2005 and represent a £135 billion investment in the NHS over two years. That is equivalent to an average increase of 9.2 per cent. for 2006–07 and 9.4 per cent. for 2007–08—an average of 19.5 per cent. over the two years. As a result of the 2006–08 allocations, Dacorum PCT will receive record increases in funding. For the current three-year allocation period, covering 2003–04 to 2005–06, Dacorum PCT has received a total increase in its funding of over £33 million, which is an increase of 31.8 per cent. For the two-year allocation period covering 2006–07 to 2007–08, the PCT will receive a total increase of £28.2 million, which is an increase of 18.5 per cent.

I realise that that will provide little comfort to my hon. Friend, who will continue to campaign passionately for Hemel Hempstead hospital, and I have no doubt that between now and any political events that may come up in the near future, he and I will be discussing it further. I hope that we will continue this debate in the Chamber after those political events and that his constituents continue to have a wonderful constituency MP who works hard on behalf of the people who put him here and will continue to do so in future.

I thank the Speaker for selecting this important topic for debate this afternoon. I know that other hon. Members who represent Scottish constituencies that have ferry ports will want to catch your eye, Mr. Deputy Speaker.

It is obvious that ferry services are important for islanders. The islands and peninsulas of the west of Scotland have been served for many years by the state-owed Caledonian MacBrayne shipping company, known locally as CalMac. The importance of shipping to the islands is reflected by the well-known parody of the 24th psalm:
"The earth is the Lord's, and all it contains, except the Western Isles, which belong to MacBrayne's."
That parody shows how important ferry services are to islanders. They dictate much of island life.

Owing to the small populations on the islands, the CalMac services are viable only because the company receives an annual subsidy from the Scottish Executive. However, because of that subsidy, European Union regulations dictate that those services must be put out to competitive tender. There is no demand from islanders for those services to be put out to tender, but tenders are being forced on the Scottish Executive by the 1992 European maritime cabotage regulations. It is important to note that that demand did not originate in Brussels. It originated much nearer home, from the British Tory Government. That Government held the presidency of the European Union in 1992 and, during the term of their presidency, they pushed the regulations through Europe.
At the start of the British presidency, the then Transport Secretary, John MacGregor—now Lord MacGregor—boasted in a written answer that he would
"take forward the increasingly rigorous application of the state aid rules in the transport sector so as to provide for full and proper competition in the single market."

He certainly succeeded in that aim: he drove the regulations through the Council. However, Lord MacGregor clearly did not have a clue what he was talking about because, in the same written answer, he said:

"The anachronism of the United Kingdom and some other member states having their coastal trades open while the rest did not will be ended."—[Official Report, House of Commons, 24 June 1992; Vol. 210, c. 247–248W.]

The written answer made it clear that Lord MacGregor was completely unaware that, within the United Kingdom, Caledonian MacBrayne-operated services were not open to competition. When, as President of the Council, he signed the legislation into law, he seemed unaware of the situation on the CalMac routes. So we have a set of European rules that were foisted on us by a Tory Government who did not have a clue about the reality of ferry services in Scotland.

It is interesting to note that the legislation came into effect on 1 January 1993, yet here we are 12 years later without Britain being compliant with the regulations. During the latter years of the Tory Government, both Secretaries of State for Scotland—now Lord Lang of Monkton and Lord Forsyth of Drumlean—wisely ignored the legislation that their Cabinet colleague had promoted. Even the arch-privatiser, Lord Forsyth, decided that it was a privatisation too far.

The Commission noticed eventually that the United Kingdom was not complying with the legislation and shortly after the establishment of the Scottish Parliament in 1999, it ordered the Scottish Executive to comply. However, the Scottish Executive have found it difficult to comply with the legislation and, after six years of discussion and consultation, they have still not succeeded in coming up with a workable solution.
It is important to remember that the legislation was designed to open up the lucrative sea routes to holiday islands in the Mediterranean and the Aegean to competition.
I am grateful to the hon. Gentleman for his intervention. I was not aware that the Greeks were still not complying, although I knew that they had a derogation until 2004.

The measure is completely impractical for the unprofitable routes in the west of Scotland. In the second half of this year, the UK will again hold the EU presidency. My purpose in requesting the debate was to draw the House's attention to how unworkable the proposal is, and, assuming that the Government are still in office and that a certain event does not remove them before then, to ask them to use the power and influence of the presidency to get these unworkable European rules changed, so that the tender does not have to go ahead. A British presidency was responsible for creating this mess; let us make another British presidency bring it to an end.

I now want to turn to why the European rules are unworkable in the west of Scotland context. If left purely to the market, there would be sailings only to the larger islands and in winter, even those large islands would receive a very poor service; the small islands would have no service at all, so a subsidy is clearly necessary. Under the EU rules that means a tender; a tender means a contract and a contract must have a tight specification. That means complete timetable inflexibility for the six years of the contract. Under the current arrangements, no one in the public or the private sector would dream of trying to set a ferry timetable six years in advance, but under these rules, that is what has to be done. Until now, timetables have been reviewed every six months and can be altered as circumstances change. That flexibility will go with the tender.

Six years is the maximum length of the contract that the EU rules allow, but a six-year contract is clearly not long enough to allow the operator to think of the long term and develop the services. The vessels themselves will still be the property of the Scottish Executive, but the operator will be responsible for the maintenance during the six years of the contract. A vessel normally has a working life of about 25 years, but the operator will simply skimp on maintenance and not care what state the vessels are in at the end of the six-year contract. We all know that we look after our own car far better than a hire car, and that is inevitably what will happen in this case.

The European legislation ignores the fact that shipping services comprise many elements: vessels and crews, and land-based infrastructure such as piers and harbours. In order to implement the legislation, the Scottish Executive will be forced to set up a vessel-owning company with the generic name of Vesco and an operating company with the generic name of Opsco. They have to be set up as two separate companies instead of being integrated into one company, as at present. Clearly, that will cause problems.

The piers and harbours are owned by many different organisations, some by CalMac, some by local authorities, some by trusts. A multiplicity of contracts between Vesco, Opsco and the port and harbour authorities will be necessary, which reminds me of the railways fiasco. The situation has been called Railtrack on water and we are heading for the same sort of mess.

Another problem is what happens if the operator, Opsco, goes bankrupt. I doubt if the Scottish Executive will have retained the expertise necessary to step in and pick up the pieces. Any private shipping company asked to step in at short notice will be able to hold the Executive to ransom. After only a few days without a ferry service the islands will start to run out of food and other essential materials.

In order to compete with the private companies, CalMac will be forced to transfer the employment of its crews offshore to avoid paying United Kingdom employers' national insurance contributions, which will cost the Treasury £1 million a year. Under the EU rules, the Scottish Executive cannot insist on the vessels remaining under a UK flag; they can sail under the flag of any EU country. But other EU countries have lower standards for training and expertise of the crews than Britain, so standards will inevitably fall.

In order to enforce a contract it clearly needs penalty clauses for lateness or failure to complete a sailing. However, that also leads to problems. Already, because of the penalty clauses in rail contracts, connecting trains will not wait at the station if the boat is late. We will now be faced with the same situation with the ferries. The boats will not wait for the late trains for fear of the penalty clause.

Inevitably, we will get into a situation when passengers from the train at Oban, say, could even be sprinting along the pier, only to see the captain order the gangway up in order to avoid the penalty clause. To some small islands, the next sailing could be three days later. That is clearly a farcical situation, but it is what we will be faced with under a penalty clause system. A huge majority of my constituents want CalMac to continue to operate these lifeline services. CalMac has its faults—nobody would say that it is perfect—and it certainly has plenty, but a public body can be lobbied and pressurised into making changes, whereas a private sector body will be interested only in conforming to the timetable, avoiding penalty clauses and making a profit.

Crews often live on the islands and are part of the local community. In the small islands, a large proportion of the work force work for CalMac. The crews have a commitment to those islands, whereas a private operator, with crews possibly from the far side of Europe, will not have same commitment to the island communities.

The legislation has already wasted a great deal of taxpayers' money. CalMac has spent considerable sums engaging consultants and has devoted a great deal of time and energy to preparing for the tendering process that would have been better spent improving ferry services.

One of the principles of the European Union is subsidiarity, which is supposed to be about devolving power to local communities. However, the Scottish Parliament is against the tendering, as are the local communities. The Government should back those communities in Europe.

As I have said before, the Tory Minister who was responsible for the legislation had not a clue about the situation in the west of Scotland. He was simply following the "if it moves, privatise it" ideology that gave us Railtrack. Rail privatisation failed. I know that my hon. Friend the Member for Orkney and Shetland (Mr. Carmichael) wants to catch your eye, Mr. Deputy Speaker, and he will be able to tell the House how these regulations failed the Northern Isles.

It is also interesting to note that the regulations do not apply to buses. European Governments can subsidise buses without the need for competitive tenders. There is no sense in the rules applying to ferries but not to buses. The Scottish Executive could subsidise the bus to Skye without a tender, so why not the ferry to Tiree? There is no logic in that at all.

I have explained all the problems that the regulations will cause. In the second half of this year, Britain will be in a uniquely influential position in Europe through holding the presidency. I urge the Government to use that position to persuade the Commission and the Council of Ministers that it simply does not make sense to enforce the rules in the fragile economies of the peninsulas and islands of the west of Scotland. They were designed for the lucrative Mediterranean, where competition might make sense. However, it does not make sense in those fragile economies.

This unwanted legislation could well wreck those economies completely. It was never designed for such a situation. I remind the Minister that even Lord Forsyth shied away from implementing it. I hope that the Government will not support such a privatisation and I appeal to them to do all that they can to end these unwanted and unworkable rules.

I congratulate my hon. Friend the Member for Argyll and Bute (Mr. Reid) on securing the debate and on having presented a detailed and cogent case on behalf of his island and peninsula communities. I know well the importance of such services to his constituents, as I was born and brought up on one of the islands in his constituency, as well as representing an island constituency.

My hon. Friend highlighted a number of the problems that have resulted from competitive tendering. Such problems are well known to us in the Northern Isles because we are one step down from the situation currently faced by the Western Isles. We have had one round of competitive tendering. The tender was called in early by the Scottish Executive and we are now going through the tendering process for the second time. Many of the fears that my hon. Friend outlined today have been well founded in our experience.

The matter to which I wish to bring the House's attention today, and on which I seek Government support, is that in the course of the re-tendering process, we have been told that the EU Commission has decided that state aid rules should exclude livestock transportation, so that livestock is to be treated in the same way as any other freight transport. The impact of that on Shetland farmers and crofters is an increase of up to 50 per cent. in the costs that will be exigible for the transportation of sheep and cattle to mainland Scotland. My farmers and crofters are already operating on exceptionally tight margins, so that will be a critical issue to be resolved in the next few months.

Yet again, I find myself frustrated in the extreme that although state aid rules are intended to ensure open competition, they operate in a narrow, restrictive way that excludes constituents of mine and, I suspect, other peripheral island communities from participating in the marketplace. The European Commission is supposed to operate according to the treaty of Amsterdam, subject to the special treatment of peripherality, as it is called. Island and remote communities can be treated differently, and it is an immense source of frustration to me that that never seems to apply in practice. It is a small point, but I hope that if the opportunity arises for the Minister to support our case, she will do so.

I should like to congratulate the hon.
